message: Of course, I'd like to say http://www.glancely.com is the coolest thing I've ever built, what with the jQuery and the Python and image analysis and suggested results/instant search and such.  But I still consider it a work in progress. :-)
oh, I typed it wrong.  http://holono.com/ozzie_gooen
Very cool site. And you go to Harvey Mudd!  A very cool school.

There was a question from the Startup School application in 2010 that asked what the coolest thing you've ever built was.  So, I thought I'd ask you all here.  What's the coolest thing you've ever built?

A guy from my very first "full time" job went there.  Super smart guy and probably an underrated school.  I think the team that founded DreamHost went there as well.  Shame the name sounds like one a cartoon character would have.
I did a similar thing with color filtering that was fun to code. It involved generating color palettes and computing color distances using Delta E.

I'll start with an old project... I built a test stand for one of the world's first digital hearing aids.  It combined Pascal/Assembly with signal analysis (stuff like Fourier transforms and filters). There was even a section of assembly code that executed between samples.  I had to count clock cycles there to make sure the code completed before the next sample was taken.  Then I graphed results and had a whole menu-driven process to test and analyze the aids.  I did that in the summer in about 3 months as an intern.  In the end, it all worked.  (Too bad the hearing aid itself was before its time and flopped.)
@ogooen but the topic was perfect so I had to show it in the meantime.  Also, because Holono probably is the coolest thing I've ever built.
Haha, I'm happy you know of it.  I'm studying abroad now in Singapore, and am used to people assuming it's a really poor place because they haven't heard of it.

Just want to say, I'm working on a website to show off the "Coolest thing you've built".  Why limit your explanation to 3 lines?

It's Holono, a website that allows you to make pages like this:
http://holono.com/users/ozzie_gooen

We're in a period of transition, and are planning to release as a Beta in a few days.
@ogooen Oh, if we can *see* the work, that's much cooler than having to just explain it.  But the URL you gave said "The page you were looking for doesn't exist."
It's also a work in progress, but it can still be quite useful now
OC-12 network via geosynchronous satellite. The last item on the schedule was to maneuver the spacecraft back to Earth, to burn up in the atmosphere. All projects should end with fireworks.
Yea, it's not the best name.  Fun school though.   btw, nice job with Glancely.  Is it mainly for clothing?
@dabent It took me a minute to figure that out.  You may want to replace "Instant Product Search" with "Instant clothing search" or something.  I started at first by looking for ipods.
@ogooen Yup, think Hipmunk for clothing shoes and accessories.
@DGentry Very cool! So the spacecraft had an "exit strategy" like many 1990's internet companies...
@ogooen Great suggestion!
It only worked because I was too fresh at programming to realize that it should have taken years to write, but all in all, it was awesome.

First serious thing I wrote was a callcenter management app; Included a knowledge base, ticket tracking, etc.  Interfaced with the mail system to see who was going to be in meetings, interfaced with the phone system to see who was on break, and automatically scheduled around those sorts of things.
The coolest thing I've ever built is always what I'm working on at that moment.  Even at 38 I have the fascination with software development of a 10 year old.
@cmoore So what are you working on at the moment?
Thanks!
You had me at "mutant vehicle." Really cool site!

http://walterthebus.org - a Burning Man mutant vehicle. Each page is a unique design. Two ladies designed the site, I developed it. The people who built the bus are super nice and fun to hang out with: http://www.walterthebus.org/the-scoop/tribe-walter/

@dabent Yea, I had the same initial reaction as @ogooen: "product search --  great it can help me find a new laptop!"...which promptly came up with some (admittedly beautiful) pictures of dresses and lap pillows :) So i think "product search" might imply rather more broad than what's being delivered at the moment.
@ryanm Thanks!
@gg You guys are giving great feedback and some new ideas. :-)
@dabent Beautiful work on Glancely.
A lossless compression technology.
@dabent Why did you delete my last message?

@dabent : Playing around with the webkit/gtk+ bindings for haskell to make something like http://www.adaptivepath.com/aurora/ .  So far it's pretty fun, but far away from as nice and polished as that looks.
poop
wtf cool is a chronism relative etc i like it when ppl stalk me on facebook to ask me if i am the author of something i wrote more than a decade ago KTHXBYE
In fact, I don't think I can delete messages on here, because I see two I'd really like to delete.
@ryanm I didn't delete any messages.  Maybe a Convore admin?
@paologlim http://shout.codecampr.com/6Hgx
so far this is the coolest thing i've ever built http://shout.codecampr.com :D
@cmoore Any video related hacking is cool to me because I don't understand it. :-)
@dabent haha! thanks!
http://strangrchat.com but I'm working on another project which I think is more cool than that, of course will let you guys know once I'm ready
Right now it has to be http://laserey.es, if only for being the latest and the one where I got to use the most new cool technologies :)
@dabent Sorry, I must have deleted it by accident.
@kilian http://s1.i1.picplzthumbs.com/upload/img/40/9e/72/409e72e587bdf5470d56911c05c6acce51cfbb09_400r.jpg
The peak of my programming career was an open-source links, article management system I developed years ago. Nothing notable since.

http://talentopoly.com is the coolest thing I've ever built. Not just because of the technical implementation of it but fostering the community that is growing on it has been a thrill! (Shameless plug: If you want an invite, just request one on the site and I'll make sure you get one.)

Our startup is currently building Mobile awesomeness in the Valley: http://www.zapon.com in 2 Weeks we will be ready with the first release of the App. So that's what we as a team have built so far that is pretty neat.
I built a grade tracking website for students (http://www.getachiever.com). I actually like it, because it's snappy and intuitive. Not that cool, but solid.

The coolest thing I've ever built was a very crappy typing tutor... it's the coolest because 10,000 people downloaded it (personal best). I've made things that are "cooler" in other ways, that are objectively better programs, but the real measure of your work is if other people use it

I once built a PLSQL driven business intelligence dashboard, all because I was too lazy to do all the analysis by hand. When I was done, we were 700% faster, and from what I was told the team used the system for over a year since I left, meaning ~million bucks in operational savings! My latest coolest thing was PresenterMate (http://PresenterMate.com) - I built that baby without having a clue how Objective-C works. Oh, actually, I built the BI dashboard without knowing any PL-type of sql either. ... I guess at the end of the day syntax doesn't matter, it's the problem that matters.

We have just openend the Private BETA of zapon - http://bit.ly/hN4Nzu - With zapon you can communicate in real-time with other people, all based on your favorite Interests - Join us in the Interest Graph Revolution! http://bit.ly/hN4Nzu So our greatest thing is in BETA now :)

I built an unbreakable 'big-brother' style distributed surveillance network for the federal government.  All the cameras and routers were bomb-proof, shock-proof, water-proof and radiation-proof.  The routers communicated over satellite, multi-homed cellular data, WiFi and (where possible) copper-based broadband back home to a data analysis array that performed facial recognition, license plate recognition and performed smart sensor based anomaly notifications to the geographically closest agents to respond.
That was pretty cool, and hit my buzzword quota for years to come.
I spent about 6 months building a social networking aggregator and content distributor called Zood and then later, www.klydo.com. That was a fun project.
@bmelton ah, so it's you we should blame! ;)
@simonify What ever happened to kyldo? any idea? I was just reading about it and it seems it has been a while since the blog was updated etc?... I think this is a fantastic idea!

@ZoFreX Actually, I believe they pulled it out of production when they had to move data centers, and it never got put back online.  They still have the cameras and routers, but currently don't have any data center to stream it back to.  They've got at least $45 million in equipment ... just sitting idle.
@bmelton dude. I'm not sure if I should applause or hate. Build any back doors into it? lol

@jngox3 we worked on it for 6 months until around December 2009 when my co-dev and I decided to get jobs so that we could continue to self-fund the project instead of getting investment. After about 2 months in to the job we realised that we didn't have time to even build the app anymore as our jobs were that demanding (we both joined a company as the lead devs/designers).

@jngox3 so we agreed to take a break from building it. After about another 3 months we came up with the idea for www.interstateapp.com and decided to start building that instead as it was only a small app. After we released the first BETA after a few weeks we got some awesome feedback and so decided to keep developing it instead of Klydo (which we put on indefinite hold for now).
@simonify Well I think it's a great concept and you guys did well. Congrats! .. Hopefully you can fire it back up at some point =)

I'm a back-end guy, I built http://mybucket.co to help me remember things. It's the first project where I self taught myself on how to do front end development (html5, css 2.1, css 3, non-inline jquery, etc). I think it looks pretty good now =)
@didip, I think mybucket is awesome! I've been dreaming about something like this, even though evernote kinda does this! LOL :P
@didip I've trouble verifying my email. It keeps leading me to "500: Internal Server Error" page. When I tried to login through mybucket homepage, it also shows me the same error page.
Back int the day I built a PHP script that used calculus to round the edges of images, using png-24 to fade the edges to give a very smooth look
A pump with no moving parts that was 30% more efficient than its closest rival that's now used as part of a drug delivery system for ICU patients

Shortly before the dot com crash I built a wireless broadband internet service provider that covered the area in and around Vienna. It was a crazy time, had to fight the government regulators all the time while dealing with scaling issues, where scaling meant climbing up 90 feet high transmission towers and installing new equipment while hanging upside down (Luckily that part was handled by a business partner of mine).
